articles.headline: Report Criticizes Comey but Finds No Bias in F.B.I. Decision on Clinton
articles.snippet: An inspector general report gives President Trump new ammunition to criticize the F.B.I., but it does not fit into his theory that agents conspired to help Hillary Clinton.
articles.abstract: An inspector general report gives President Trump new ammunition to criticize the F.B.I., but it does not fit into his theory that agents conspired to help Hillary Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s inspector general on Thursday painted a harsh portrait of the F.B.I. during the 2016 presidential election, describing a destructive culture in which James B. Comey, the former director, was “insubordinate,” senior officials privately bashed Donald J. Trump and agents came to distrust prosecutors.

articles.headline: As Uncertainty Clouds Economy, Europe Pulls Back on Easy Money
articles.snippet: Political turmoil, slowing growth and the prospect of a trade war fail to deter Europe’s central bank from ending economic stimulus measures.
articles.abstract: Political turmoil, slowing growth and the prospect of a trade war fail to deter Europe’s central bank from ending economic stimulus measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIGA, Latvia — A trade war with the United States looms. Populists have taken power in Italy, posing a new threat to the euro. Growth is sluggish, and there is even talk of another banking crisis.

articles.headline: Power Companies’ Mistakes Can Cost Billions. Who Should Pay?
articles.snippet: Utilities say they must be shielded from liability or the electric grid will suffer. Critics say that puts the burden on ratepayers, not investors.
articles.abstract: Utilities say they must be shielded from liability or the electric grid will suffer. Critics say that puts the burden on ratepayers, not investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: FALLBROOK, Calif. — After flames rolled over the hills north of San Diego and engulfed vineyards, avocado groves and neighborhoods, hundreds in this area were left with only the charred remains of homes and businesses. For many, that moment in 2007 was the beginning of a long struggle to rebuild — if they did at all — and recover their financial losses.

articles.headline: Workers Flee and Thieves Loot Venezuela’s Reeling Oil Giant
articles.snippet: Our correspondent visited Venezuela to see whether the country could pull itself out of its economic free fall. The outlook was not encouraging.
articles.abstract: Our correspondent visited Venezuela to see whether the country could pull itself out of its economic free fall. The outlook was not encouraging.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL TIGRE, Venezuela — Thousands of workers are fleeing Venezuela’s state-owned oil company, abandoning once-coveted jobs made worthless by the worst inflation in the world. And now the hemorrhaging is threatening the nation’s chances of overcoming its long economic collapse.
articles.byline: By William Neuman and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Report Gives Trump an Opening, but Undercuts His Narrative
articles.snippet: A 500-page report, the most comprehensive look at the investigation into Hillary Clinton’s use of a private email server, reflected a messier reality than the story line promoted by the White House.
articles.abstract: A 500-page report, the most comprehensive look at the investigation into Hillary Clinton’s use of a private email server, reflected a messier reality than the story line promoted by the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The report that had much of Washington buzzing on Thursday required 500 pages to outline its findings, but to President Trump, three words mattered most — “we’ll stop it.”

articles.headline: For Pruitt Aides, the Boss’s Personal Life Was Part of the Job
articles.snippet: Senior staff members at the E.P.A. said they frequently felt pressured by Scott Pruitt to help in nonwork matters and obtain favors for his family.
articles.abstract: Senior staff members at the E.P.A. said they frequently felt pressured by Scott Pruitt to help in nonwork matters and obtain favors for his family.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior staff members at the Environmental Protection Agency frequently felt pressured by Scott Pruitt, the administrator, to help in personal matters and obtain special favors for his family, according to interviews with four current and former E.P.A. officials who served as top political aides to Mr. Pruitt.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Steve Eder, Lisa Friedman and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Watching the World Cup in a War Zone, Where Every Goal Matters
articles.snippet: The tournament’s opening game provided a welcome distraction for Ukrainian soldiers in a war zone far away from Moscow, even though it was Russia on the field.
articles.abstract: The tournament’s opening game provided a welcome distraction for Ukrainian soldiers in a war zone far away from Moscow, even though it was Russia on the field.
articles.lead_paragraph: AVDIIVKA, Ukraine — Headquarters for the 2nd Battalion of the 92nd Brigade of the Ukrainian Army is in a pummeled building that once housed the district road repair agency. War has left the building in even worse shape than the roads. At the entrances, sandbags and tires are stacked in fortification. Logs reinforce the basement ceiling against the shelling.

articles.headline: Pregnancy Discrimination Is Rampant Inside America’s Biggest Companies
articles.snippet: Many pregnant women have been systematically sidelined in the workplace. They’re passed over for promotions and raises. They’re fired when they complain.
articles.abstract: Many pregnant women have been systematically sidelined in the workplace. They’re passed over for promotions and raises. They’re fired when they complain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many pregnant women have been systematically sidelined in the workplace. They’re passed over for promotions and raises. They’re fired when they complain.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: U.S. and China Expand Trade War as Beijing Matches Trump’s Tariffs
articles.snippet: The tariffs on China by the Trump administration shift what has primarily been a war of words between Washington and Beijing into a full-blown trade war.
articles.abstract: The tariffs on China by the Trump administration shift what has primarily been a war of words between Washington and Beijing into a full-blown trade war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Friday escalated a trade war between the world’s two largest economies, moving ahead with tariffs on $50 billion of Chinese goods and provoking an immediate tit-for-tat response from Beijing.

articles.headline: Harvard Rated Asian-American Applicants Lower on Personality Traits, Suit Says
articles.snippet: Personal ratings brought down Asian-American applicants’ chances of being admitted, according to an analysis filed by a group suing the school for bias.
articles.abstract: Personal ratings brought down Asian-American applicants’ chances of being admitted, according to an analysis filed by a group suing the school for bias.
articles.lead_paragraph: Harvard consistently rated Asian-American applicants lower than others on traits like “positive personality,” likability, courage, kindness and being “widely respected,” according to an analysis of more than 160,000 student records filed Friday by a group representing Asian-American students in a lawsuit against the university.

articles.headline: A Grass-Roots Afghan Peace Movement Grows, Step by Step
articles.snippet: Fed up with the relentless bloodshed, dozens of ordinary Afghans brave blistered feet and roadside bombs to carry a message of peace across hundreds of miles.
articles.abstract: Fed up with the relentless bloodshed, dozens of ordinary Afghans brave blistered feet and roadside bombs to carry a message of peace across hundreds of miles.
articles.lead_paragraph: GHAZNI, Afghanistan — As they march for peace through Afghan villages laced with roadside bombs and bottomless heartache, their numbers keep growing.

articles.headline: Judge Orders Paul Manafort Jailed Before Trial, Citing New Obstruction Charges
articles.snippet: Paul Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign chairman, had his bail revoked after he was accused of trying to influence the testimony of two of the government’s witnesses in his case.
articles.abstract: Paul Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign chairman, had his bail revoked after he was accused of trying to influence the testimony of two of the government’s witnesses in his case.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge revoked Paul Manafort’s bail and sent him to jail on Friday to await trial, citing new charges that Mr. Manafort had tried to influence the testimony of two government witnesses after he had been granted a temporary release.

articles.headline: Trump Has a Few Things He’d Like to Get Off His Chest
articles.snippet: The president said a new Justice Department inspector general report exposed the “scum on top” of the F.B.I. and showed “total bias” against him.
articles.abstract: The president said a new Justice Department inspector general report exposed the “scum on top” of the F.B.I. and showed “total bias” against him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He assailed the “scum on top” of the F.B.I. who were out to get him. He suggested that a former aide did not lie even though he pleaded guilty to lying to investigators. And he distanced himself from his onetime campaign chairman hours before the aide was sent to jail.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Eileen Sullivan
